articles.title: Announcing Welch Summer School 2026
articles.preview: A remarkable opportunity for high school students and freshmen to engage in hands-on crystallization research this summer.

body.full_title: Welch Summer School 2026: Hands-on Research Experience
body.image_caption: Students working in the lab under the mentorship of senior researchers.
body.lead_text: The Welch Center for Advanced Bioactive Materials Crystallization is pleased to announce the Welch Summer School 2026. This initiative offers a remarkable opportunity for high school students and freshmen who are passionate about science, technology, and research.

content_blocks.content: Participants will engage in scientific research focused on crystallization and its applications within pharmaceuticals, energy, and agriculture. They will have the opportunity to work in the laboratories of the center's seven faculty members from three different departments, benefiting from the guidance and mentorship of over 30 postdoctoral fellows and Ph.D. students.

The program is scheduled to run from June to August 2026, with flexible start and end dates to accommodate participants' schedules. To ensure students can fully engage with the work, applicants should have at least one year of chemistry experience. Each participant is typically paired with a postdoc or a PhD student who acts as a daily mentor, assisting with experimental training, project guidance, and helping them integrate into the lab environment.
We regularly collaborate with faculty across the college to organize lectures and activities aimed at introducing students to STEM research, academic pathways, and related career options.

We are proud of the positive impact our previous summer schools have had. Last year, 11 high school students and freshmen from various schools and universities around Houston gained invaluable hands-on experience in our state-of-the-art laboratories. This year, we anticipate admitting an even larger cohort of enthusiastic learners.
If you have any questions or need further information, please don't hesitate to reach out to smhatre@central.uh.edu.

articles.title: Nurturing Innovation: Summer Students 2025
articles.preview: Eleven dedicated high school and university freshman students embarked on an exciting journey, preparing for future endeavors in scientific research.

body.full_title: Nurturing Innovation: Summer Students Develop Research Skills and Futures at the Welch Center
body.image_caption: The 2025 cohort of summer researchers at the Durga D. and Sushila Agrawal Engineering Research Building
body.lead_text: Eleven dedicated high school and university freshman students are embarking on an exciting journey, preparing for future endeavors in scientific research and industry.

content_blocks.content: At this pivotal moment in their careers, they are being mentored by experienced researchers at the Welch Center for Advanced Bioactive Materials Crystallization, immersing themselves in a variety of inspiring research themes. The center's researchers are not only spearheading innovations but also cultivating the next generation to confront the challenges of the dynamic field of crystallization, crucial for advancements in healthcare, energy, and environmental sustainability.

These students are engaged in meaningful research that has the potential to benefit humanity. Among them, Kayla Nguyen, a freshman, and Sarah Morrison, a junior in Chemical Engineering at the University of Houston, are making significant strides. Kayla's exploration of evaporation methods in pyrazinamide crystallization, a vital treatment in the fight against tuberculosis, exemplifies the impact of this work. Sarah, alongside freshman Imad Shaikh from the University of Texas at San Antonio, is investigating the crystallization and growth patterns of cholesterol in blood vessels, seeking ways to manage its development.

Sravya Dutta, an incoming junior in Cell and Molecular Biology at Baylor University, is delving into biocrystallization studies under the mentorship of senior researchers, laying a solid foundation for her future career. High school students Krithika Srinivas, Mahika Shah, and Sanjita Chinta are witnessing firsthand the transformative nature of scientific research and its application for the betterment of society.

Beyond bioactive materials, several students are channeling their efforts into optimizing catalysts for energy extraction. Kaiden Stassen, a freshman at UH, is developing methods to create bifunctional zeolite catalysts, employed in the oil and petrochemical industries. Raquel Nwosu from the University of Texas at Arlington is enhancing the catalyst effectiveness by modifying microstructures. Penda Diop (Houston Community College) and Annabelle Choi (Carnegie Vanguard High School) are also exploring ways to amplify the catalytic activity of zeolites through innovative functionalization and structural transformation.

content_blocks.content: The guidance from the center's experts, paired with access to state-of-the-art facilities, is shaping a bright future for the biomedical and energy sectors in Texas and across the nation. The invaluable experiences that these students are accumulating at the center are nurturing the seeds of innovation and creativity, laying the foundation for a transformative future that holds great potential.
